docs.snippet: LEAD: Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the recent dramatic declines in stock markets worldwide showed the need for large countries to better coordinate their economic policies.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the recent dramatic declines in stock markets worldwide showed the need for large countries to better coordinate their economic policies.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The European Community pleaded strongly today for the United States to cut its budget and trade deficits and for Japan to help lift the world economy by opening its markets to foreign goods.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The European Community pleaded strongly today for the United States to cut its budget and trade deficits and for Japan to help lift the world economy by opening its markets to foreign goods.

headline.main: On Granting Visas; Help Another McCarran-Walter Victim

docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States will cut its 1988 sugar imports by 25 percent, to the lowest level in more than 100 years, the Reagan Administration announced today. The action is expected to increase prices for consumers and hurt the debt-burdened economies...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The United States will cut its 1988 sugar imports by 25 percent, to the lowest level in more than 100 years, the Reagan Administration announced today. The action is expected to increase prices for consumers and hurt the debt-burdened economies of some of America's trading partners among developing nations.

headline.main: U.S. Cutting Sugar Imports In Blow to Trading Partners

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Deep in the mountains of northern Honduras, 500 American National Guardsmen and Army reservists from New York, Pennsylvania and West Virginia are building a road that will help farmers in the fertile but isolated Yoro Valley bring their produce...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Deep in the mountains of northern Honduras, 500 American National Guardsmen and Army reservists from New York, Pennsylvania and West Virginia are building a road that will help farmers in the fertile but isolated Yoro Valley bring their produce to market.

headline.main: U.S. Guardsmen Building Road in Honduras

byline.original: By BERNARD E. TRAINOR, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Skip Novak remembers the incident clearly. It was a day in August two years ago when the keel fell off the 77-foot maxi-yacht he was sailing near the southwestern coast of England. Water came rushing through the hatches as the boat turned belly...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Skip Novak remembers the incident clearly. It was a day in August two years ago when the keel fell off the 77-foot maxi-yacht he was sailing near the southwestern coast of England. Water came rushing through the hatches as the boat turned belly up.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Economic crises in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina, occurring simultaneously for the first time since Latin America's debt troubles began five years ago, are casting a pall over the region's relations with its foreign creditors.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Economic crises in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina, occurring simultaneously for the first time since Latin America's debt troubles began five years ago, are casting a pall over the region's relations with its foreign creditors.

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: A novel proposal to help Mexico reduce its $105 billion foreign debt burden by more than $10 billion was greeted throughout Latin America today as a significant step toward easing the region's six-year debt crisis.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A novel proposal to help Mexico reduce its $105 billion foreign debt burden by more than $10 billion was greeted throughout Latin America today as a significant step toward easing the region's six-year debt crisis.

headline.main: Latin America Hails Proposal on Mexican Debt
